commit.message: docs: update readme file with markdown templates [skip ci]

Remove copyright ending year

Reference: https://github.com/thoughtbot/templates/pull/23

Call dynamic-readme reusable workflow

We want to have a way to edit our README footer at one place and have the changes from there be propagated to our repos.

By adding this snippet in the README, we call this reusable workflow: https://github.com/thoughtbot/templates/blob/main/.github/workflows/dynamic-readme.yaml that renders and updates the README footer dynamically.

New domain for apt repo

Eric has moved it to his server.

commit.message:
Replace thoughtbot.se with thoughtbot.com

The redirect from thoughtbot.se now redirects to
thoughtbot.com/london, which had little involvement in the rcm(1)
project. Therefore replacing the uses of thoughtbot.se with
thoughtbot.com feels more applicable.

commit.message:
Expanding exclude tests to cover wildcard error cases

test/rcrc-lsrc-excludes.t: testing excludes from the .rcrc file

- testing EXCLUDES= for lsrc from .rcrc
- and testing combining excludes from .rcrc and command line (command line takes precedence)
- directory tagged exclude (eg -x "*:*~" -x "foo" ) when combined with any were broken in v1.3.4
- seems breakage was introduced between in v1.3.4

test/lsrc-excludes.t:
- added test cases for wildcards and multiple excludes
- tracked down problem to multiple excludes when one of them is directory specified wildcard

commit.message:
Clarify the SHA256 installation programs

Most people will be manually installing this using a GNU userland, so
show `sha256sum` as the default, but highlight that it might be spelled
differently for different OSes.

When GNU [added it to coreutils in 2005][], they called it `sha256sum`, to
match their existing `sha1sum`. They [renamed][] `shasum` to `sha1sum` in
2000, [called it][] `shasum` earlier in 2000 by analogy to `md5sum`, and
[named it][] `md5sum` in 1995.

OpenBSD [added the program][] in 2004, extending the existing `md5` program to
support being called as `sha256`.

It looks like Illumos and Solaris [ship with][] GNU coreutils.

RFC 6234 calls the SHA256 sample program `shatest` in section 8.5. RFC
1321 calls the sample MD5 program `mddriver` in Appendix A.

[ship with]: https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E88353_01/html/E37839/sha256sum-1.html
[added the program]: https://cvsweb.openbsd.org/src/bin/md5/md5.c?rev=1.29&content-type=text/x-cvsweb-markup
[added it to coreutils in 2005]: https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/coreutils.git/commit/?id=0ebfe3cf4b83f016ab2b6c3dc6126e9e8621e0a9
[renamed]: https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/coreutils.git/commit/?id=7bb9c7382ff3d4a31aa6e79bd03b2890d5d0ffe6
[called it]: https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/coreutils.git/commit/?id=148e5d1b4d2d9ab1a5f9523e2e1f92914f0f2be0
[named it]: https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/coreutils.git/commit/?id=84876e7e9e2b42a430aff37adc0888c4562b447a

verification.payload:
tree 79b03f002f38cd6cc998a4fd9b560ecb359bb3cb
parent 20e32cadfd282a9dfdf691186b6d323bf22bd810
author Darcy Parker <darcyparker@gmail.com> 1630071100 -0400
committer Mike Burns <mburns@thoughtbot.com> 1646428157 -0500

match their existing `sha1sum`. They [renamed][] `shasum` to `sha1sum` in
2000, [called it][] `shasum` earlier in 2000 by analogy to `md5sum`, and
[named it][] `md5sum` in 1995.

OpenBSD [added the program][] in 2004, extending the existing `md5` program to
support being called as `sha256`.

It looks like Illumos and Solaris [ship with][] GNU coreutils.

RFC 6234 calls the SHA256 sample program `shatest` in section 8.5. RFC

[ship with]: https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E88353_01/html/E37839/sha256sum-1.html
[added the program]: https://cvsweb.openbsd.org/src/bin/md5/md5.c?rev=1.29&content-type=text/x-cvsweb-markup
[added it to coreutils in 2005]: https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/coreutils.git/commit/?id=0ebfe3cf4b83f016ab2b6c3dc6126e9e8621e0a9
[renamed]: https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/coreutils.git/commit/?id=7bb9c7382ff3d4a31aa6e79bd03b2890d5d0ffe6
[called it]: https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/coreutils.git/commit/?id=148e5d1b4d2d9ab1a5f9523e2e1f92914f0f2be0

commit.message:
Move from Ruby to Python for mustache

We already use Python for cram, so this reduces the number of external
dependencies for developers. Note that it requires a program named
`python` on the path.

* Use pystache module
* Rewrite autocontrib
* Update CONTRIBUTING
* Fix all Markdown files by linting

Move from Ruby to Python for mustache

We already use Python for cram, so this reduces the number of external
dependencies for developers. Note that it requires a program named
`python` on the path.

* Use pystache module
* Rewrite autocontrib
* Update CONTRIBUTING
* Fix all Markdown files by linting

commit.message:
Remove deprecated apt-key command

apt-key has been been deprecated and is scheduled for full removal in
2022.

Remove this command in favor of the preferred method of adding public
key directly into the trusted.gpg.d folder.

source: https://salsa.debian.org/apt-team/apt/-/merge_requests/119

committer Eric Collins <eric@tabfugni.cc> 1618927029 -0400

Remove deprecated apt-key command

apt-key has been been deprecated and is scheduled for full removal in
2022.

Remove this command in favor of the preferred method of adding public
key directly into the trusted.gpg.d folder.

source: https://salsa.debian.org/apt-team/apt/-/merge_requests/119

commit.message:
Support -k and -K in mkrc

These are just passed along to $INSTALL (i.e. rcup). Support for -K
would've closed #102, except it seems already closed at the suggestion
such a PR would be accepted if create#102, except it seems already
closed at the suggestion such a PR would be accepted if created.

Adding -k is a bit dubious, IMO. The default behavior is to run hooks,
and I can't see any other way (e.g. rcrc) to change that. Therefore, -k
has no use that I can find. In any event, I added it to mkrc as well,
and tested it, for parity with rcup.

I will adjust documentation in the next commit.

tree 0c760acc2451734f4023de6cce669cd11ee5a353
parent 43c0a5820a07c15f3e6d8c0bc424072ddf17d0b5
author patrick brisbin <pbrisbin@gmail.com> 1609782278 -0500
committer Mike Burns <mburns@thoughtbot.com> 1611954689 -0500

Adding -k is a bit dubious, IMO. The default behavior is to run hooks,

commit.message:
Fewer sharp edges in mkrc

Update the documentation for mkrc(1) to clarify some common gotchas:

- Add the new file normally, then use mkrc(1) to do the dotfiles dance.
- The `-C` flag copies files and, as such, this means they are no longer
tracked. We can manage symlinks for you, but the `-C` flag is a
convenience option that takes you outside of the area we can manage.
- We really mean it about `-C` when it comes to directories. Copy it all
you want, but it is now your responsibility.

Fixes #206.

Another sharp edge is around the dotfiles directory.

- Only support one `-d` flag. It doesn't make sense to pass multiple
`-d` flags to mkrc(1).
- The argument of the `-d` flag must be a directory.

Fixes #254.

verification.payload:
tree d8c47477f62cd8c516ca80cbb737a9299b07de6e
parent 9367aa9616e1d85673f32fde1e82212023825ba6
author Mat M <matm@gmx.fr> 1587852126 +0200
committer Mike Burns <mburns@thoughtbot.com> 1611954120 -0500

Fewer sharp edges in mkrc

Update the documentation for mkrc(1) to clarify some common gotchas:

- Add the new file normally, then use mkrc(1) to do the dotfiles dance.
- The `-C` flag copies files and, as such, this means they are no longer
tracked. We can manage symlinks for you, but the `-C` flag is a
convenience option that takes you outside of the area we can manage.
- We really mean it about `-C` when it comes to directories. Copy it all
you want, but it is now your responsibility.

Fixes #206.

Another sharp edge is around the dotfiles directory.

- Only support one `-d` flag. It doesn't make sense to pass multiple
`-d` flags to mkrc(1).
- The argument of the `-d` flag must be a directory.

Fixes #254.

commit.message:
Another attempt to alphabeticalize

Martin is right: "Debian-based" being first is confusing for more
specific Debian-based OSes. Let's try being explicit about the fact that
Ubuntu is further down.

They're intentionally alphabetical so it doesn't seem like we give
higher priority to one over the other.

verification.payload:
tree 345fc1d595627d1b7afb904484db06395a5c75e2

Another attempt to alphabeticalize

Martin is right: "Debian-based" being first is confusing for more
specific Debian-based OSes. Let's try being explicit about the fact that
Ubuntu is further down.

They're intentionally alphabetical so it doesn't seem like we give
higher priority to one over the other.

the "Debian-based" chunk.

commit.message:
Update Ubuntu installation instructions

As of Ubuntu 19.04 (Disco Dingo), rcm is now available in the Universe
package repository.

The ppa will no longer be necessary for future versions of Ubuntu but
will be kept around until the older releases are EOL.

Also, add a line to ensure that `software-properties-common` is
installed. It is for instance not included in the bare `ubuntu:16.04`
docker image.

Add software-properties-common

author Martin Frost <frost@ceri.se> 1563819809 +0200
committer Mike Burns <mburns@thoughtbot.com> 1598637200 -0400

Update Ubuntu installation instructions

As of Ubuntu 19.04 (Disco Dingo), rcm is now available in the Universe
package repository.

The ppa will no longer be necessary for future versions of Ubuntu but
will be kept around until the older releases are EOL.

Also, add a line to ensure that `software-properties-common` is
installed. It is for instance not included in the bare `ubuntu:16.04`
docker image.

Add software-properties-common

commit.message:
Fix shell globbing bugs

There are several problems leading to the unintentional globbing issue:

Firstly, within `rcup` and `rcdn`, when constructing arguments to pass
to `lsrc`, the _for_ loops over the arguments do not have quoted
variables, leading to globbing.  I have quoted these accordingly.

Secondly, `lsrc` is invoked as follows:

```sh
dests_and_srcs="$(lsrc $LS_ARGS)"
```

When shells use command substitution like this, they go through two stages:

- Word expansion. This is useful because it splits `LS_ARGS` back up
into its constituent strings.
- File name expansion. The side effect of this is to introduce globbing.

You can read more about how this works [here](https://www.tldp.org/LDP/Bash-Beginners-Guide/html/sect_03_04.html#sect_03_04_07).

To fix this, I have passed `lsrc` and its arguments to `eval`.  This
involves quoting the relevant arguments, so:

```sh
for dotfiles_dir in "$DOTFILES_DIRS"; do
  LS_ARGS="$LS_ARGS -d $dotfiles_dir"
done
```

becomes

```sh
for dotfiles_dir in "$DOTFILES_DIRS"; do
  LS_ARGS="$LS_ARGS -d \"$dotfiles_dir\""
done
```

Then `lsrc` is invoked as follows:

```sh
dests_and_srcs="$(eval "lsrc $LS_ARGS")"
```

There is one final non-globbing issue: the parsing of arguments can
introduce extra spaces in the variables, which then trip up the
`dotfiles_dir_excludes` function. For example:

```sh
I) includes="$includes $OPTARG";;
```

introduces a space if `includes` is empty or null.

I have introduced the function `append_variable`, which allows two
variables to be appended without introducing unnecessary whitespace.
Then the additional whitespace is never added in the first place.

Fixes #256.

verification.payload:
tree 387a6fd63a9332e43ca9f29a4b65ada39f85f45d
parent f2fb351c391dca7c188a8623e71519619c2ce9a0
author Edd Salkield <edd@salkield.uk> 1579372845 +0000
committer Mike Burns <mburns@thoughtbot.com> 1585945267 -0400

Fix shell globbing bugs

There are several problems leading to the unintentional globbing issue:

Firstly, within `rcup` and `rcdn`, when constructing arguments to pass
to `lsrc`, the _for_ loops over the arguments do not have quoted
variables, leading to globbing.  I have quoted these accordingly.

Secondly, `lsrc` is invoked as follows:

```sh
dests_and_srcs="$(lsrc $LS_ARGS)"
```

When shells use command substitution like this, they go through two stages:

- Word expansion. This is useful because it splits `LS_ARGS` back up
into its constituent strings.
- File name expansion. The side effect of this is to introduce globbing.

You can read more about how this works [here](https://www.tldp.org/LDP/Bash-Beginners-Guide/html/sect_03_04.html#sect_03_04_07).

To fix this, I have passed `lsrc` and its arguments to `eval`.  This
involves quoting the relevant arguments, so:

```sh
for dotfiles_dir in "$DOTFILES_DIRS"; do
  LS_ARGS="$LS_ARGS -d $dotfiles_dir"
done
```

becomes

```sh
for dotfiles_dir in "$DOTFILES_DIRS"; do
  LS_ARGS="$LS_ARGS -d \"$dotfiles_dir\""
done
```

Then `lsrc` is invoked as follows:

```sh
dests_and_srcs="$(eval "lsrc $LS_ARGS")"
```

There is one final non-globbing issue: the parsing of arguments can
introduce extra spaces in the variables, which then trip up the
`dotfiles_dir_excludes` function. For example:

```sh
I) includes="$includes $OPTARG";;
```

introduces a space if `includes` is empty or null.

I have introduced the function `append_variable`, which allows two
variables to be appended without introducing unnecessary whitespace.
Then the additional whitespace is never added in the first place.

Fixes #256.

commit.message:
Do not symlink a symlink in mkrc

We have a bug when calling mkrc(1) on a symlink:

```sh
mkrc ~/.vimrc # links ~/.vimrc to ~/.dotfiles/vimrc
mkrc ~/.vimrc # deletes ~/.dotfiles/vimrc
```

This catches that case ahead of time, preventing the user from running
mkrc(1) on a symlink.

Fix #144.

verification.payload:
tree 28efb32af5fa87d62807131e85dbe1529ef23c4a
parent fb8045f1cf3c8a76cba700d4e0507992be738f89
author Mat M <matm@gmx.fr> 1575761153 +0100
committer Mike Burns <mburns@thoughtbot.com> 1579297566 -0500

Do not symlink a symlink in mkrc

We have a bug when calling mkrc(1) on a symlink:

```sh
mkrc ~/.vimrc # links ~/.vimrc to ~/.dotfiles/vimrc
mkrc ~/.vimrc # deletes ~/.dotfiles/vimrc
```

This catches that case ahead of time, preventing the user from running
mkrc(1) on a symlink.

Fix #144.
